item.description: PARTY SCRABBLE® The classic word game has a contemporary new theme with a timing feature! Score points by placing words on the playing board. But this is not ordinary Scrabble®. Play in teams with special dice. Once the timer starts, it's time to scramble! The faster you play, the more your score. Delay and your team is penalized. The team with the highest score wins! For two or more teams. Ages 10 and over.

item.description:
Star Blazers is a very simple hex-and-counter game, based on the famous Japanese anime series Space Battleship Yamato (Uchuu Senkan Yamato). The human player/s have to make a journey from Earth to the planet Iscandar and back within a limit of 26 turns (one year simulated), to save the home planet from deadly radioactivity. The Gamilon player/s have to delay the Yamato and his escort ships, coming in their way, making their path more hazardous with the use of mines and shooting missiles.

The game movement, shooting and counter-attacks are managed by a spinner. Special damage and events are activated by the 8 cards.

Game components:
1 game board
1 plastic Yamato stand-up
5 plastic spaceships
5 round plastic parts for spaceships
1 plastic turn counter stand-up
8 special events/damages cards
30 hex counters missiles
30 hex counters mines
Stickers for the Yamato stand-up and for the turn counter
1 spinner

Move it! is a simple game simulating the transport of containers at the Europe Combined Terminals. You have to move little wooden containers from a boat to one of a maximum of six stacks (rows) and then onto a truck to be transported over land. Players can block each other by stacking containers on top of each other. Decreasing the amount of stacks in play makes the game harder.

The game was commissioned by ECT (European Container Terminal) in Rotterdam, The Netherlands, on the occasion of the completion of the Delta/Sea-Land Terminal.

From a translation of the rules:

Kreuzweise was designed to play at home or when away. It is compact and the optimized material chosen for the high quality playing cards is thin, flexible and easy to clean. Where ever you play Kreuzweise, enjoy!

Basically, it's a tile-laying puzzle game where points are scored based upon the number of matching edges.

Players take the roles of antique dealers bidding for items at auction. At the start of the game each player secretly selects eight items, represented by nicely illustrated cards, of the sixteen different antiques available (the deck includes three of each type) recording these on a score pad. Each item is likely to have a different value, representing the resale value for each player. The object therefore is to purchase as many of the selected items as possible for less than the resale price.

Players take it in turns to auction the cards. The progress of each auction is unusual in being determined by die rolls. The auctioneer rolls a die to "establish the reserve". The next player in rotation can either roll again, the value shown being added to the reserve price or drop out. This continues until only one player remains in the bidding. The cost of the item is then the sum of all the die rolls!

Items other than the eight may be purchased but at the game end they will represent a loss there is no resale value) and at any point a player may offer an item or items for sale at a price to be negotiated.
The game continues until one player has accumulated his or her
portfolio of eight items, the game ends immediately and all players calculate their profits.

The largest profit wins.

'The New Property Development Board Game': in contrast to Monopoly presumably. Play comprises two stages. In stage one players travel around a a perimeter track, 'the inner ring road' on the roll of two dice, collect income on one corner and pay taxes on another. Each space represents a parking space. These give either an option to purchase either property or pick up a card and follow the instructions on it. The object is to collect a complete site made up of ten back-land plots together with a drainage easement. When a player has achieved this, movement moves to the outer (ring road?) track that is meant to represent the process of obtaining Planning Approval for the development. This is achieved by firstly collecting cards giving recommendations for approval from three separate local authority departments and then being the first to land on the town hall space: yes, on the roll of the dice and, yes, doubles mean another go!

item.description:
Number 5 in the Mystery Rummy series

Welcome to the 5th in a series of Mystery Rummy games, all created by Mike Fitzgerald!

Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow were notorious outlaws who robbed banks throughout the central United States between 1931 and 1935. Their exploits and charisma made them famous, and their story has been made into books and movies. Ted Hinton was the FBI agent charged with capturing them.

You are an FBI agent competing against other agents to see who can catch Bonnie and Clyde. The object of the game is to be the first to score 100 or more points.

There are two types of cards used in this game: Evidence (Location) cards and the Ted Hinton card. The game is played like the classic Rummy card game, with players playing melds and layoffs of Evidence cards to score points. The Ted Hinton card adds a strategic element to the game not found in traditional Rummy. After each hand, you total your points, and if no one has 100 or more points, you play another hand.

item.description:
Front line by Bandai
This is a man to man level tactical combat in WW2.
Some gamers ranks this game high, especially when the details of weapon is concerned.
Another feature is there are self adhesive terrain stickers are included.
They stick to the mapboard (hard board) and are easily pealed off so they are re-usable.
This game has companion game called "Shin-ei-tai", which means "the Guards" or "SS".

This is a Japanese hypothetical setting game, based on a WW2 level weapon system.
This game is intended to be an "introductory" game for newcomers.

This game portrays the battles of El Alamein, Dunkirk, 3rd Kharkov. Operation Compass is only included in Japan Wargame Classics edition.
Simple I-go, You-go system makes this a complete beer & pretzel package.

COMPONENTS (Epoch edition and Command Japan edition)

 1 rulebook
 4 map board (1 for El Alamein, 1 for Dunkerque, 2 for Kharkov) 
 1 countersheet




COMPONENTS (Japan Wargame Classics edition)

 4 rulebooks (4 pages each)
 4 map sheets (A3 size for "El Alamein" "Dunkirk" and "Operation Compass"; A2 size for "Kharkov")
 1 countersheet
 1 primer guidebook (32 pages)




System and "El Alamein" designed by Yukihiro Kuroda.
"Dunkirk" designed by Masaharu Nakano.
"Kharkov" designed by Hiroyuki Okuyama.
"Operation Compass" designed by Takuya Sakamoto.

Spots is a card game in which two or more players will make change from a pool of cards. Scoring is handicapped based on the difference between the total of a player's starting cards and the lowest total of the opponent's starting cards.

Players put one card from their hand into the pool, taking cards with a total value equal to or greater into their score pile. The player with the lowest score after all cards have been played wins.

Spots was designed to be a card-based version of Pennywise. It was first published in the Origins 2000 preregistration book.

Strike Them A Blow: 1864 North Anna River , is the fifteenth entry in the Civil War Brigade (CWB) Series from MMP. This is #15 in the series and covers the North Anna Campaign in 1864 and finally takes the system to the late Civil War period. As Robert E. Lee, can you keep the Union forces at bay, as they probe the length of the North Anna River, and the Pamunkey River? Will Cold Harbor be the pit of despair that it was in 1864? Or. as Grant, will you be able to outmaneuver Lee, and breach the outerworks of Richmond ending the war early? Only your skills will be able to dictate the course of The Civil War.
Solid game system with excellent components.

Components:

2 1/2 inch countersheets

2 34x22 map sheets.

item.description:
This is a Japanese game on "Operation Barbarossa."

This game won the 1st prize in the design competition presented by Sho-Kikaku.

A remake Blitzkrieg to Moscow 2 was published in 2016.

An operational level wargame on carrier warfare in the WW2 Pacific theater. It covers from the raid on Pearl Harbor to the Battle of the Eastern Solomons, and also includes two fictional battles.

Players will control either carrier task force of the Imperial Japanese or United States Navy. Players manage fleet organization, fleet movement, search for the enemy and aircraft operations. Search system uses the dummy counters and the information chits.

The winner is determined by victory points based on damage inflicted to the opponent ships. Players also earn VP for strategic objective achieved or prevented.

Scenario
1. Attack on Pearl Harbor (Dec 7, 1941) Solo
2. Sinking of Prince of Wales and Repulse (Dec 10, 1941) Solo
3. Battle of the Java Sea (Feb 27, 1942) Solo
4. Carrier vs. Carrier (Fictional)
5. Battle of the Coral Sea (May 7-8, 1942)
6. Battle of Midway (Jun 4, 1942)
7.ã€€Battle of the Eastern Solomons (Aug 24-25, 1942)
8. General Fleet vs. Pacific Fleet (Fictional)
9. Battle of the Santa Cruz Islandsã€€(Oct 25-27, 1942) - Command Magazine Japan #15 and Japan Wargame Classics
10. Campaign of Solomons (1942) - Command Magazine Japan #15
11. Indian Ocean raid (Apr 5-9, 1942) - Command Magazine Japan #15 and Japan Wargame Classics
12. Assault on Solomons (1942) - Command Magazine Japan #15


Components (First edition)

 1 rulebook
 3 counter sheets (about 400 counters)
 7 map board (3 - 197 x 296 mm; 4 - 306 x 406 mm)
 2 reference cards
 2 fleet organization cards
 2 aircraft operation cards
 1 counter tray




First published as "World War Game (WWG)" series #8 by Epoch Co. in 1982.
Reprinted with Command Magazine Japan #10 in 1996.
Reprinted as Japan Wargame Classics #1 in 2009.
Reprinted as Historical Simulate War-games Series 004 (Chinese Version) by AURORA GAME STUDIO in 2019.

item.description:
The Cuban Revolution depicts the critical area and time in the Guerrilla war fought between the colonial government of Fulgencio Batista and the Guerrillas led by charismatic individuals like Fidel Castro and Ernesto “Che” Guevara. Beginning in February, 1958 Castro began the first Guerrilla offensive by coming out of the Sierra Maesta Mountains and attacking the Bastiano troops in the plains. The Bastiano army counterattacked driving the Guerrillas back into the mountains beginning in June 1958. When the Bastiano army attempted to destroy the guerrillas, the Bastiano army was all but destroyed itself. With all the newly acquired weapons, the guerrillas launched a final offensive that ended in the only major battle of the war at the town of Santa Clara. The defeat of the Bastiano western forces caused the rest of the army to begin deserting. When Batista fled in January 1959, the guerrillas triumphantly declared the island was finally free. The improbable victory of the Guerrillas resulted in the only communist country in the Western Hemisphere.

The Cuban Revolution uses area movement and a simple and easy-to-learn combat system. Learning the game takes minutes and about 1-2 hours of playing time at most.

In the early morning hours of March 6, 1836, after a thirteen-day siege, the besieging Mexican army surrounding San Antonio, Texas, launched a surprise attack upon the presidio of the Alamo, which was defended by U.S., Texan and Tejano volunteer militia units. The cheering Mexican soldiers, along with the accompanying bugle call of the “Deguello”, soon betrayed the surprise attack. Within an hour and a half, the entire garrison of 182 to 225 volunteers had been “put to the sword,” and General Santa Anna had won his victory at the cost of some 311 of his brave officers and soldiers. Even more, he created an American myth that began with the “Deguello at Dawn”

Dennis Bishop uses area movement, facing, ranged fire and melee combat to recreate this famous event in American History. Leaders play a big role in the game and rules for Col. James Bowie to determine if he's healthy and able to take part in the battle.

A unique twist on casualties is also used as the game has a large map (17" x 22") and uses over 400 double sided unit counters (some that are 1½" x ½") as well as about 8-10 pages of rules and various game player aids.

Deguello at Dawn was a nominee in the Charles S. Roberts awards for Best DTP-Produced Boardgame (Charles S. Roberts Awards) for 2005.

The Battle of Tanga was the first major movement by Britain during World War 1 against the German East Africa colony. A diverse mix of colonial troops from India took part in the landings. Plagued with numerous problems, the British pressed on against the outnumbered German Schutztruppe and their Askari soldiers.
The object of the game is to catch marbles through holes in a vertical maze as the marbles fall from top to bottom.

Space Race is a simple card game designed for two players, though more can play with additional card sets (as there is no player interaction whatsoever).

The object of the game is to complete a round trip through the Solar System by drawing ten planet cards in their proper order. (The order will be unfamiliar, though, as it goes Earth -> Saturn -> Jupiter -> Mars -> Uranus -> Neptune -> Venus -> Mercury -> Earth). Each card features well executed art done in a style similar to golden age science fiction pulp magazines.

The game consists of two identical decks with cards numbered 1-10. These cards represent round trips the the Solar System, starting with "Take Off" (Card 1) and ending with "Landing On Earth" (Card 10). Players take a deck and shuffle it, then place it before them. The first player draws a card. If it is "Take Off" (Card 1), they place it in front of them and draw the next card. If the next card is a planet but not Card 2, they discard it in a discard pile next to their original pile and draw again, until they draw a card that says "Next player goes". The next player takes a turn, and draws until they get a "Next player goes" card. Chance cards such as "lost on the moon," "Sputnik," and "Danger--Comets" can affect a player's turn.

Players may draw from either pile, so there is a memory element, as you must remember which pile your next planetary target was in.

All cards must be discarded in the pile next to the pile from which they were drawn.

The goal is to collect all 10 cards, in sequence.

Rules list a variant for three or more players through using multiple copies of the game.

item.description: The Medabots Trading Card Game, based on the children's television cartoon of the same name, allows two players to compete by placing Medabots on a Battle Sheet and fighting it out. Whenever a Medabot is destroyed, players pay a cost in Hit Points. The player who causes his opponent to lose all his HP is the winner.

name.value: Rainbow Fish and the Big Blue Whale Game

item.description:
From the box: Join Rainbow Fish and friends in a race through the ocean. Be the first player to reach the krill feeding ground and you win!

This action-filled game, based on Marcus Pfister's book, Rainbow Fish and the Big Blue Whale, will take you on many adventures. Try to avoid the obstacles in your path, such as getting sent back by the angry blue whale's swooshing tail or getting trapped in the cave.

This is a children's bingo game with a Mickey Mouse Theme. Each player receives a bingo card with a 5x5 grid of Disney characters with different colored backdrops. A spinner is used to call spaces. The outer circle of the spinner shows the various characters while the inner circle shows colors (5 per character). For example: If the spinner arrow points to the color blue and Donald Duck's face, "Blue Donald Duck" is called out. Any player with a Blue Donald picture on their card would cover it with a chip. The first player to cover 5 characters in a row with chips wins.

Similar in some regards to the Ace of Aces book series, Duel Master takes 2 players, each with their own book, into competition with one another. Play is paragraph based, with each player making their own choices about what they want their character to do.

In the Arena of Death the players take the roles of gladiators in the arena in the city Mortavalon.

item.description: This children's card game, with a Mickey Mouse travel theme, is actually four games-in-one. In the first game, players draw an outfit card and then simultaneously grab clothing cards off the table, racing to be the first to find all four articles of their characters outfit. The second game is a simple memory game where players turn over face down clothing cards trying to (once again) complete their characters outfit. In the third game, players add an item to Mickey's suitcase and must then repeat every item (in order of the ever growing sequence) that has already been packed. The forth game is a simple rummy variant in which players try to collect all four pieces of clothing for any outfit by drawing cards from the deck or asking opponents for a specific type of card.

Game given by Dutch coffee company Douwe Egberts to customers which had collected a lot of coupons found on their products.

Theme of the game is coffee (really!); you are a coffee seller buying raw harvested beans and rights for different production phases (blending, roasting, packaging and distribution) to optimize the profit from selling your coffee. You can trade coffee and rights with other players.

One can also buy stock in one of the production plants (squares on the board); when you land on that square you get the rights for free, when others land on it they buy rights from you instead of the bank.

It resembles Monopoly (though it is different enough not to be called a clone) and has a similar limited-but-existing possibility for using strategy.

This is basically the same as the first Simpsons Trivia Game, but with different questions. The game contains purple and green (!) cards with trivia questions as well as the same character die and poster as the first game.

This version also has different character card games: Who's Who in Springfield, Whose Wise Remark is That, and The Answer is a Question. A sheet of quotes from various characters is included for the second game.
A Japanese wargame on an important campaign in Nobunaga's history.

From the new Trafficking web site:

TRAFFICKING is a role-playing board game that spoofs the cannabis trade. The game features eight dealers - Reefer T. Johnstone III, Janet Planet, Zerox Roachoid, Sonny Sgurd, Stephie "Honey Oil" Slick, Biff Spliff, D.J. Stoner and Fast Eddie Toke c pitted against a dedicated, hard-nosed Narcotics Officer, Lieutenant Dick Gumshoe. The object of the game for the dealers is to become the "Traffic King", that is to be the first dealer to sell a kilo of marijuana (36 ounces or "lids") before being BUSTED by the Narc. Should the Narc succeed in busting all the dealers before any sells a kilo, the Narc wins the game.

This classic was originally released in 1983 but is now back to get another generation of gamers high on fun!

item.description: A race with dice. To get your die into the race roll it. Place it on the matching position. Move a die as many spaces as the die shows. If you move over another die it will change its number. First player to reach the finish line wins.
Move your pawns over clouds to win a race.

This game is based upon the popular BBC television soap.

From the box:
"The characters down in Albert Square have seized the imagination of the country and here's your chance to share in the ups and downs of their lives by taking on the part of one of the residents of TV's most famous square."

The goal of the game is to obtain the money to buy two rings, and then reach their character's "objective" space. Each character also has certain spaces to avoid as they move around the board. Some spaces allow the character to wager money on the dice. There are other spaces which allow all of the players to vote on how a character would respond to a dilemma given on a card.

(From the game box)

The exciting game of instant decisions... Decide what your strategy will be... Make the call, throw the special dice and hope they roll your way. That's "Call It"!

Predict your dice throw and CALL IT, in this wild race game. You can Advance yourself, Setback your opponents, or do both if you CALL IT right. With the right calls, you'll be the first to reach the Finish Line. SO get ready, get set, and CALL IT!

"Measles, the ultimate stacking games, combines the elements of balance, coordination and luck with strategy of attempting to outscore an opponent, or gain a scoring advantage of at least five points.

Game components include 1 base tile and 29 wooden playing tiles. Each playing tile has a pattern of red spots (measles) on its surface. Every measle is scored as one "spotpoint" following completion of a round of play.

Each of the 29 playing pieces also has 3 randomly drilled holes in it. This gives every playing tile a unique weight and balance."
...from the rules

This card game is intended to be played while watching a televised basketball contest. Each player is dealt a hand of seven cards, each with a basketball "event" such as slam dunk, blocked shot, free throw, and rebound. When a player has a card that matches the event that just occurred on the televised game, they must be the first to play it, thereby scoring the points on the card for that event (the rarer the event the more points). When a player plays all seven of their cards, he gets a seven point bonus, everyone tallies their scores and a new hand is dealt. Play continues until the end of the game and the player with the most points from completed rounds is the winner.

This is a party game for 4 or more players. The person whose birthday it is fills out a special bio questionnaire. Teams move around the board performing silly tasks and answering silly questions to advance. The first team to reach the Birthday Cake space gets a chance to answer the bio questions. The team that answers the most questions correctly wins.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

name.value: Great Day in the Park Game

item.description: This is a Candyland type track game with a Raggedy Ann & Andy theme. The board depicts a park with a trail winding through it. On your turn, you draw a card and advance to the next space whose color matches that on the card. If you draw a picture, you move to the space on the board that has the matching picture. If you land on a puddle space, you lose a turn. The first player to reach the balloon space at the end of the track wins.

Fun about stereotypes and truths.

"Why men lie and woman always buy shoes" - Who doesn't know these stereotypes? In this party game, the players note their Top-5 on a specific man-and-woman theme. This theme is either determined through a random card or made up by the players (with a picture as inspiration).
The items on Top-5's of the players are compared. Items that appear on the lists of several players are worth victory points. Therefore, while playing the game, you should try to expect what other players will put on their Top-5 list. What can women do better than men? What do men always have in the refrigerator? During scoring, fun surprises are guaranteed.

item.description:
Ages 10 - 16

Manufacturer's Summary:
"The game created for girls, by girls" The questions and activities all revolve around your friends, your teachers and your classmates.

Teen and pre-teen girls love to gossip about EVERYTHING. Now, there's a game designed to encourage fast-paced, fun and non-threatening conversation that helps girls know more about themselves and each other. Your girls will love it!!

This game was designed to be a stand-up version of "Twister";

Players have to perform various actions without falling, while intertwined in a long stretchy cord.

In Tip of the Tongue, you need to answer trivia questions as quickly as possible, which might leave you tongue-tied in the process. The game includes more than a thousand trivia questions, and while the questions aren't hard, you need to spit out an answer in two seconds. How quickly can you do it?

This Canadian offering is a hybrid of card lottery and poker, played with a large scoring board and nine differently-colored decks of cards (one for each player, plus a "dealer" deck).

The games is played in rounds, where the dealer plays a number of cards face-up, and one face-down. Players decide whether the round will be lottery-style (person with the most matches to the dealer's hand wins), or poker-style (bidding on your hand plus cards from the dealer's hand).

As an added bonus, the game promises to (and I quote from the box): "...help you and your friends lighten and brighten gloomy days, warm up cold ones and cool off hot ones."

A roll & move game to teach Spanish. Ages 8 and up.

From the back of the game box: Pack up your knowledge, memory, and luck and get ready to roll on a Road Scholar Spanish journey. From the START at the airport to the END at the Ancient Ruins, you'll have great fun learning an amazing amount of Spanish as you navigate the perilous twists and turns of the road.

Components: game board, English instructions, 300 word and phrase cards, Two 60-minute audio cassettes, playing pieces, colored die.

Game instructions are provided in English.

Publisher's web site: http://www.pentonoverseas.com/road-scholar.htm

A "look-carefully" game about abstract and spatial thinking.

The cars are parked hither and yon all across the parking lot - but illegally-parked vehicles get towed immediately! But which cards are parked incorrectly? The players need a keen eye to help out Petra the meter maid.

In Maus nach Haus, the members of a mice family race to jump into the mouse hole before the other families can – but they're stymied in their efforts by a mouse hole that never stands still! Each round, one player spins a wooden ring, making it rotate on the table; before the ring slows and falls to the table, players simultaneously flick their mice tokens with their fingers to try to place them inside the "mouse hole" when it lands. Any mouse in the ring is removed from the game, and the first player to bring all his mice home wins.

Hula Hippos features the same game play as Maus nach Haus, but this time players have circus hippos that they're encouraging to leap through the hoop. The first player to be hippoless wins.

item.description: There is a gadget that slides discs of differing size down one side, simulating a waterfall. On the discs are cubes of different colors which represent different points. If you cause these cubes to fall off during your turn, they will belong to the player before you. So this is a mix of dexterity and push your luck game.

This is a "Cootie" type game in which players try to assemble one of the Mickey Mouse Club characters. On your turn you spin a spinner to see what body parts you may add. The characters MUST be assembled in an upright position, so the legs must be added first, then the body, and lastly the arms and head. The first player to complete a character wins.

Each player plays a character who starts the game as a teenager and then must choose the cards that will make his life take shape. He can repeat a school year and get new friends, start smoking, take part in a Bible discussion group and have his first sexual intercourse during Oktoberfest – all very realistic. Every event in the life of a character has some effect on his main characteristics - tobacco addiction, alcohol addiction, drug addiction, wealth, health, sadness, spirituality and wisdom. Excess comes at a price, though, and when a characteristic gets too high, it cancels another one – if you smoke too much, you get thin; if you get too fat, you must stop drinking; if you drink too much you lose your wisdom, and so on – once more, very realistic. During game, you can get friends, and often more, with other player’s characters. This is an important feature in the game, since what happens to you usually affects, in good or bad, your friends, and this is one of the main interaction aspects of the game.

Description from Bruno Faidutti's ideal game library.

item.description:
Kai Haferkamp is developing into a specialist in converting children's literature into games. After 'The Little Prince' comes this year's The Little Ghost, based on the book by Otfried Preussler. The game picks up the storyline about the players, on the stroke of midnight, spending the witching hour flitting through the dark halls of Castle Eulenstein with the little ghost. Whenever the great clock in the city hall marks the passing of another hour, a picture shows up in one of the viewing windows. Whatever is shown on the picture is what the children must now find behind the closed doors of the castle. They accomplish this with the help of a mysterious magnetic set of keys that, as if through the hand of a ghost, opens the doors of the old castle. For each correctly-opened door one receives a gleaming cannonball. How many of these balls will be required for victory is decided only by the final dexterity game in the knight's hall.

Ages 5 and up

item.description: This children's pizza game, with a Mickey Mouse theme, is actually 4 games-in-one. In the first game, you pop the popper die and find the pizza that matches the shape popped. You "deliver" the pizza to the character whose hands are shown on the card. The player who delivers the last pizza wins. Game #2 is a memory game. You pop the popper and turn over a pizza card. If it matches the shape and color of the pizza you popped, you take the character card that ordered that pizza. The player with the most character cards at the end wins. Game #3 is a typical memory game where players try to get the most matching pairs. Game #4 is an advanced version of Game #1.

One year after releasing the highly-regarded game and art object Die HolzerSiebeN by Friedensreich Hundertwasser, Kosmos is releasing another art game, this time with James Rizzi - albeit in a much lower price category.

The game idea, invented by Reiner Knizia, is very simple but tense. The 28 large Rizzi art cards have values between 0 and 6; each of the two players receives twelve. On a player's turn, they must discard a card from their hand. To discard, a player must either create a new discard pile or place the card on an existing discard pile - but in that case, the value of the card must be exactly one higher than the card onto which it is to be placed. If there are already three discard piles on the table, then a player has no choice but to discard to one of the piles. If he can't, then he has lost the round and receives as many glass beads as cards left in his hand. The first player to get six glass beads is the loser.

James Rizzi is part of the Kosmos two-player series.

As of 2006 -- It appears that this game may never have been published.

item.description: Pizzas seem to be popular with Kosmos these days. In addition to the 'Pizza of Catan' (a promotional tie-in with a Geman pizza company), they are publishing a game called Pizza Flitzer (Pizza Speeders) by Gordon MacLeod. Paul and Paula are the fastest pizza deliverers around. Their good reputation is influenced by the fact that pizzas occasionally slip out of their hands. Clumsiness? Nope! Paul and Paula can simply only deliver pizzas that they are magnetically attracted to. Pizzas of the wrong pole rebuff Paul and Paula. The two of them need a little help. Someone will surely remember which pizzas the two of them should be delivering. The game includes a round wooden game board that looks like a pizza with an arrow spinner in the middle, nine magnetic pizza pieces and two magnetic figures. The two figures, Paul and Paula, have different poles (positive and negative) to ensure that they are never attracted to the same pizza. The spinner determines which figure a player, on their turn, may hold over a pizza piece. If they choose correctly, the pizza, with a click, fastens itself to the figure. The winner is the player who owns three pizza pieces first.

Heinrich Glumpler is well-known for his original game ideas. With Zauberstauber (Magic Duster), he's tackled witches - but not the kind of witches that are known to most, that is, wrinkled old crones that fly about on dusty broomsticks. His new generation of witches are totally hip and savvy, and they use high-tech vacuum cleaners to take to the skies - those would be the Magic Dusters. The complicated magical duster technology makes special demands of its pilots. In the good old days, you could simply sit on your broomstick and fly off. But now, the flight pattern of the duster must first be properly programmed into the machine. No surprise then, that witches who aren't yet completely familiar with the new technology often end up on the wrong track while programming their flight routes.

item.description: This game features a Mickey Mouse dressed like a baker. He stands on a wobbly base and holds an empty tray in each hand. All players take an equal number of pie pieces from the supply. On your turn, you place one of your pies on either of Mickey's trays. If you place it without having it, or any other pie already on the tray(s) fall off, your turn is over. If the pie falls, or knocks off any of the pies already on Mickey's trays, you must take the fallen pies and add them to your supply. The first player to get rid of all of his or her pies wins.

This is a Japanese science fiction wargame set in the anime world of Xabungle.

This is a ground combat game in Zola.

This is a tactical ninja wargame based on the struggles between Iga and Koga clans in Japan.

Published by Bandai.

This game is an area type game.
However, "Storm Over Arnhem" is different systems.


 Setup
 Decide Ninja's ability
 Ninja's ability (eight abilities) is decided(Movement,Detection,Magic ability,Combat Rating,Quickness,Physical strength,recovery power,Ninjyutu).
 It gives a name at the end. 
 
 Appearance unit
 Ninja and Samirai;Casket;
 The ninja turns inside out at the time of initial arrangement and arranges it. 
 The back is disguised as the samurai. 
 
 



 System
 Sequence of Play
 


1.First Player:First movement Phase
2.First Player:Combat Phase
3.First Player:Second movement Phase
4.Second Player:First movement Phase
5.Second Player:Combat Phase
6.Recovery Pahse:Both Player

 Basis of movement
 It is not possible to move diagonally though a length movement or a horizontal movement can be done because it is an area type movement. 
 The movement can be moved the below the floor level and back of the ceiling.

TWO CIVIL WAR BATTLES: VALVERDE & OLUSTEE

Tactical scale: 75 yards/hex, 100-125 men/unit

DTP format with unmounted color counters and color map

This is a Japanese tactical level game on the battles of the 1944 Western Front during World War 2.
Platoon level game of tactical battles.

Eleven scenarios from June 1944 to December 1944 from Normandy to the Bulge.

Tank types of the German, British and US armies are there.

SGB-20 Op. Winter Storm (1986) (JPY 5,800) One mapsheet, 504 counters, two identical PACs, one 24-pg rule/scenario booklet (3 scenarios), and one Historical Softbound book entitled “Photographic Series of the East Front-Operation Winter Storm” (72-pg) (JPY 1,800). The historical softbound appears to have been available separately, but I have three copies of this game and they both came with this item.

Unit scales are infantry divisions, armored brigades/regiments and Soviet Mechanized Corps. Losses are handled by steps with extra Kampfgruppen for the Germans. The map stretches from Rostov-na-Donau to Stalingrad and from Kotelnikovo to north of Millerovo. Each turn is four days and covers Nov. 19th thru Jan. 21st. Supply is tracked by point for individual armies.

item.description: In this game, players assume the roles of Power Rangers on a 3-D gameboard. First, you must roll at least a "5" to turn into a Ranger. Then, you must defeat the Putty patrols on your path by rolling a number higher than the patrol's strength. Power Chips may be used to increase your die roll. Once all the Putties are defeated, you roll two dice to battle the Space Alien on your path. For the final battle, you roll three dice to attack King Sphinx. If all players have defeated all the Space Aliens, a Megazord is built allowing players to roll four dice in the final battle. The first player to defeat King Sphinx wins.

name.value: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Audio Game

item.description: This is actually 2 games that use an audio cassette to direct the game play. Game #2 (Side B on the tape) is a more complex version of Game #1 (Side A on the tape). To start each player takes a board that depicts all 5 Teen Heroes. The tape will tell you when to draw cards and when to battle. The object is to cover your Heroes with their Power Ranger counterpart cards. A Rita Repulsa card may be played on an opponent to make him or her lose a turn. A Putty card is immediately discarded (thus wasting a draw). A Space Alien card may be placed on an opponents Power Ranger card forcing that player to play another Ranger card on that space. A Megazord card defeats a Space Alien and/or prevents further attacks on that space. The first player to morph all the Teen Heroes on his or her game board into the corresponding Power Rangers wins.

From the publisher:

Four angry families quarrel in the labyrinth-like garden about the fruit. The fathers send their sons to collect the fruit while they try to steal it from the other's sons. The maze changes with every turn and if you don't pay attention, you'll get nothing home at the end.

From the publisher's website:

You try to build bridges on your construction-site. This results in real chaos and soon the first parts will be falling to the ground. Try to keep your eye on your strategy to get the highest score. Limited edition of 150 pieces, numbered and signed by the author.

Each player gets four little plots on the back of the game-box. Depending on the number of empty plots, a player gets material at the beginning of his turn. Now he can use this material to build connections between his plots. There are different building-styles which are more or less difficult and therefore result in more or less points. A player can also use the already built parts of the other player, which is easier and therefore results in less points. If you manage to build very complicated connections, you'll get more points. After a while, the board will be full of chaotically arranged bridges. If something falls, you'll get penalty, so be careful! Once all plots are connected, the game is over and if you didn't plan carefully you again get a penalty.

name.value: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers War of the Zords

item.description: This game, featuring a Power Rangers theme, is similar to the card game "War" with a few added twists. The deck is dealt out face down evenly among the players. Cards depict Power Rangers, bad guys, or puzzle pieces. Each player simultaneously turns over their top card and the player with the highest value card wins them all. If there's a tie, the tying players continue turning over cards one at a time until someone turns over a higher value card. The player that wins the trick takes all point cards and places them in a separate pile (to be counted up later). Then the winner collects all puzzle cards and puts them in the center of the table either starting or adding to a puzzle. There are 2 six-piece puzzles: one depicting a Megazord, and one depicting Rita Repulsa. The game ends when either puzzle is completed. If the Megazord puzzle is completed, the point values on Power Ranger cards are added up. If the Rita Repulsa puzzle is completed, the point values on bad guy cards are added up. The player with the most points is the winner.

The game is a round trip through Switzerland, departing from and returning to Zürich. Distance is determined by die roll and there are no branches in the route, the only option being to choose to travel clockwise or counter-clockwise. Each player has six place cards, and if he or she stops at a place owned by another must pay that person one chip or miss a turn. The winner is the player with the highest total of chips plus bonus points gained by early completion of the journey.

Publication date is not specified but is probably early 1960s. The box cites both Franz Carl Weber/Jouets Weber (Swiss toy company and chain of shops) and Otto Maier Verlag (later Ravensburger: the box is printed "Ravensburger Spiele Nr. 23"). Otto Maier published a different game of the same name in 1891.

Trimula appears to be an implementation of 3D Noughts and Crosses. It looks from the box that it was released sometime in the early 70s. The contents consists of a clear plastic 3D game board which can be assembled and disassembled at will, and a more than adequate number of large glass marbles in two colours. However whilst it is a game in a 3 x 3 x 3 matrix, it has very different win conditions to Tic Tac Toe in that the player with the most row of 3, when the pawns are all played, wins.

There are a number of other such games where the players use 3 boards arranged to yield 27 playing positions.

The Stars Our Decimation is the name for a series of interrelated science fiction wargames built around the actions mechanic. TSOD games all feature hand-built rules, hex grid regulated movement, a unique actions system, and versatile unit design rules.

Voidstriker is one of the games in the series. It is a fleet-oriented game of starship combat. Ships and fighters battle in deep space and in the gravity wells of important worlds. The rules feature unique, playable vector movement with gravity effects around planets, versatile ship design rules, quick and detailed combat resolution, and easy adaptation to use of miniatures or starship models.

Ground Zero is another game in the series. It is a tactical ground combat game, best suited to running company-level combats. Rules are based strongly on Voidstriker, so if you know one, you'll have a pretty good handle on the other.

Undercut is a game created using Icehouse Pieces. It's an auction game where the players score points based on sets of similar pieces, but the twist is that the player with the lowest score wins. During each round, players are required to bid on a set of pieces, and it is desirable to win the auction on the set of pieces which most avoids matching pieces.

Game System

 Icehouse Pieces

item.description:
Board (6x4)
Players should agree whether they play with rows of size 6 and columns of size 4, or with rows of size 4 and columns of size 6.

Rules
Players each have the following pieces: one king, one queen, and two pawns. They may setup their pieces as they want on the first rank of their side of the board.

It's probably better if players alternately setup one of their pieces, with the kings deployed last. Using a screen in the middle of the board behind which the pieces can be set up secretly may also be an idea, but poses both practical difficulties.

King and Queen move as in orthodox chess.

Pawns have the usual moves of chess, but may also move diagonally.

Quotes from the box:

item.description:
Travel Blokus is the smaller, 2-player verson of Blokus. It is an abstract strategy game with transparent, tetris-shaped, colored pieces that players are trying to play onto the board. The only caveat to placing a piece is that it may not lie adjacent to your other pieces, but instead must be placed touching at least one corner of your pieces already on the board.

The tiles in the Blokus To Go version are made with square holes cut into them that allow them to be snapped onto square-shaped "nubs" on the playing field. There are also two storage trays that hold the tiles for travel. These trays cover the board when the game is not being played and fold open in order for players to access the tiles.

link.value: Divisible By Zero (DBZ) Aust Pty Ltd

name.value: Stock Rush! A Week on Wall Street

item.description:
BRIEF SUMMARY:

Stock Rush is a Strategy Board Game that uses an Interactive Device called the "Market Display". PLAYERS WATCH THEIR STOCKS FALL, RISE, CRASH and SKYROCKET . . . RIGHT BEFORE THEIR EYES! For added excitement, players also Mine for Gold and participate in a Gold Rush! The "Game Play" in Stock Rush is so unique and diverse that it spans many game categories including: Strategy, Family, Party, Simulation, Educational, Action and Adventure!
 
For 2 to 10 Players, Ages 8 and up.

DETAILED SUMMARY:

Game play begins on The Opening Bell space and a peg is used to keep track of the trading day. Players can play a regular game and spend a full business week on Wall Street [Mon-Fri] or they can play a shorter game by starting on Wednesday. The game usually ends when the trading day peg reaches “Game Over” which is the slot after Friday. Other ways the game can end are: “Market Collapse” in which all companies go bankrupt; One player left in the game after all the other players go bankrupt and All players are trapped in a Cave In. At the end of the game, all players liquidate [sell] their holdings to the bank and the player with the most cash wins the game.

STOCKS . . .

Players buy and sell [Trade] stocks at the current market price shown by the "Market Display" [4 Stocks comprise the market in the game, A,B,C and D]. The stock prices are affected by news and rumors that randomly occur throughout the course of the game. There are two types of news and rumors that occur: Market News and Rumors affect the entire market; and Company News and Rumors which only affect a given individual company. Although rumors occur at random; how long they remain alive can be strategically predicted. The longer a rumor remains alive the higher the chance it will be confirmed or dispelled on the next turn. Consequently, players must trade accordingly; they must decide on 4 Criteria: [1] Buy or Sell?; [2]Which Stock to Trade?; [3] How many Shares to Trade?; and most importantly [4] When to Trade?.

COMMODITIES [MAINLY GOLD] . . .

The Stock Rush name was inspired by the California Gold Rush of 1849. As a result, a significant portion of the game is dedicated to that historical event. Players randomly mine for Gold and participate in many Gold Rushes throughout the game. During a “Gold Rush” players may become trapped in a “Cave In”. Trapped players may escape on their own or be rescued by other players. 
Once players accumulate Gold they may strategically sell any amount they wish on the "Gold Exchange Market". They must sell according to 3 Criteria:
[1] How much Gold to Sell? [2] At What Price to Sell? [3] When to Sell? The other commodities in the game are Groceries, Toys, Clothes and Gear…the STUFF we use in our everyday life.

item.description: Hands on soccer much like the "bubble" hockey games of today where two players face off in a match of dexterity and control while moving the soccer ball down the field.

name.value: Brice de Nice: Kass contre Kass
Cartes à Collectionner du Père Noel
Cowboys and Indians Mini Card Game
GI Joe War Jumbo Card Game
Jackie Chan Adventures Kung-Fu Match Game

item.description:
War can be played with a standard 52 card deck as well as special themed decks of different sizes.

The deck is dealt out evenly to the players into face down piles. Both players then turn their top card face up. The player with the higher value card takes both cards and puts them face down at the bottom of his or her pile. If the cards have equal value, there is a war. Both players place 3 cards face down (occasionally, some people play with the modified rules of 1 or 2 face-down cards instead of the standard three) on the table and then place another face-up card on top of those. If the two are equal, they place more face-down cards and add another face-up card (etc.) The winner of the round once the most recent face-up cards are different in value takes all of the cards currently on the table. The game ends when one player has the entire deck.

link.value: The United States Playing Card Company

item.description:
This is a simple track game based on the Mighty Mouse comics. On your turn you roll the die and advance the number of spaces indicated. If your roll would land you on an opponent's pawn, you move backwards instead. If you land on a hazard space, you are stuck, and must spend your next turn(s) moving the Mighty Mouse piece to your space. When Mighty Mouse reaches your space, he releases you and any other player caught in a hazard. The first player to reach the Finish space by exact count wins. If your roll would take you past Finish, you move backwards instead.

This is seemingly a different game from Terrytoons Mighty Mouse Game

Roll and move board game involving Wildlife Hunting. Very attractive board with three revolving sections. Nice period colors on the box illustration. Game includes cards representing animals and tokens representing the hunters

A soccer game where you decide every turn to move, pass or shoot on a large checkerboard pitch. You take your team of 9 players and move them around the board in order to defend your goal or to take the ball to your opponents goal and score.

name.value: Hawkeye and the Last of the Mohicans

item.description: Strange shooting game with stand up sections with six Mohicans riding horses. The object to knock over the figures with a rubber suction cup dart gun.

One player becomes the cat, while the others are mice. The cat rolls a die with six different colors on it, and then attempts to catch the corresponding player's mouse with a little wooden cup. (In order to avoid smooshing of little fingers, each mouse is connected to a cord!)

Similar to:

 3 Blind Mice
 Carla Cat
 Nopea veto

link.value: HABA Game in a Tin series

item.description: This children's memory game features an electronic plastic cow and 4 milk glasses. On your turn, you take a cookie from the cookie jar and dunk it into one of the glasses. If you hear a "Boing!", the glass is empty so put the cookie back. If you hear a "Mmmooo", you found the milk that goes with that cookie - keep it and put it on your plate (the "Mmmooo" moves to another glass). If you hear a "Mmmooo" and the cowbell, you may trade plates with another player. The player with the most cookies on his or her plate when the cookie jar is empty is the winner.

Rare board game set around buying and selling stocks and shares determined by advantage and dis-advantage squares on the playing board, the game is for 3 to 7 players.

Each player takes the part of a broker and is dealt stock cards and money to start the game. Play moves around the board on the throw of the dice.

Do you sell shares or buy shares? You could go for oil, gold, rubber etc.. Wheel and deal is the order of the day.

If a broker is unable to pay a debt in full, he is said to be hammered - Therefore out of the game. The objective is to be the last remaining broker left standing when all the others have been hammered.

The Brokers in the game Are called:
Knight and Day
Spenlow and Jorkins
Dunn and Haddit
Dimple and Curve
Catchem and Bending
Hookem and Havem
Dodgson and Fogg

Early Chad Valley game with six target animals and box that opens up into a shooting gallery. The complete game is includes wire frame spring gun that fires wooden missiles. Nice lithography inside and out.

Try to get as many pawns to the opposite side as possible. 
You can kick out your opponents pawns.
One player is a thief the other one a police officer. The thief tries to get out of the city without getting caught.
Place Native Americans around their Tipi. Earn points by placing them on the good spots.
You own a travel agency. You sell space vacations. Get the most tourists to visit the moon to win this game.

In this game players try to spell the word "Millionaire". Each player is dealt 7 letter cards. To start, you begin by laying down the letter "M" and any other letters (in sequence) that you can. If you cannot make a play, you draw a card instead. The other players also add letters to the word (if possible) on their turns. When the word "Millionaire" is spelled out, the player having the fewest cards left in his or her hand scores points equal to all the cards left in the opponent's hands. The first player to score 75 points is the winner. Rules for playing "Card Anagrams" are also included.

Milton is an electronic game where players try to complete phrases. It plays 3 different games but all of them have the same basic mechanics. On your turn, you press a red phrase button and listen as Milton speaks the start of a phrase like "Blink your". You then press one of the yellow answer buttons and listen to the response (in this case you're trying to find "eyes"). If you are correct, you take another turn. If you are incorrect, your turn ends and Milton ridicules you. When all the phrases have been matched with their endings, the player who made the most matches wins.

[FROM THE RULES]

The game of modern masters: Impressionism to Surrealism.

ARTDECK is a game that offers art lovers and game players aesthetic pleasure and an exciting way to learn about modern art. Play the game as directed, play other games of your own, or just enjoy the images on the cards. ARTDECK will enrich your leisure hours.

A 3-D strategic games with rhombic dodecahedrons to build a pyramid.
Each piece piece has 6 white sides and six black sides.
The contents are 30 plastic pieces, 2 playing grounds (triangular and square), and instructions.
The main game (Cuckoo) is to place your piece at the top of the pyramid. You can prevent your opponent from reaching that goal through clever piece placement.

Variants include Zebra and Ant rules.

The monster bakers are hard at work in the kitchen – but to be honest, they're all terrible bakers, filled more with enthusiasm and drive than baking talent. Thus, you need to help them assemble the ingredients they need in order to complete the cakes on order!

To set up Monstertorte, place all of the ingredients – wooden balls in six colors - in the mixing bowl, that is, the box bottom. On a turn, one player reveals a cake card, then all the assistant chefs use their wooden spoons to scoop out the proper ingredients and assemble them in their individual bowl. The first player to do this wins the card, and the first player to collect five cards wins.

item.description:
This is a set of rules for Minatures in the Napoleonic era. Originally published in 1971 as Napoleonique, it was revised and reissued in 1992 as Napoleonique Encore.

Here is the description from the back of the Encore edition: 
"Napoleonique /Encore covers the wars of the French Revolution through the many campaigns of Napoleon and to the final battle of Waterloo in 1815. You select the battalion or regimental game from scales set up to accommodate your current mounting scheme. The focus on simplicity will have you finishing a turn in twenty minutes with armies of a thousand or more.
The original rules called Napoleonique, set battalion level games at a scale of thirty men per casting, a ten minute time scale and twenty yards per inch. Napoleonique/Encore offers 5 game scales with casting representing 30 men in some scales up to 90 men in the regimental version. These rule shave a history of being the beginners friend and the veteran's "first car" in wargamming.
Napoleonique/Encore is a product of the team of Jim Getz and Glenn Davis. Over 20,000 copies of the original Napoleonique were sold since its release in the early 70's. Some of you may buy Napoleonique/Encore for nostalgic reasons while others will find the simplicity to be a pleasant change. Either way we know you'll enjoy these rules."

name.value: Tausend Namen von A bis Z

item.description:
Try to name a word which begins with the letter A and with B and then with C - so on through to Z. That won't be too difficult! But when the word you name has also to belong to a particular group or type of thing, the whole thing becomes much more tricky!

A word game. On a board with 20 letters from A to Z, the players try to move to the last letter by finding words. The players get cards with a generic term and have to think of a word, which falls under this term. In the beginning the players start with the letter A. They have 30 seconds of time. If they cannot come up with a letter the card goes to the next player on the left, who now has to think of a proper word. If the player finds a suitable word, he moves to the next letter. As soon as one player reaches the letter Z the game ends.

A fun language skills game for Ages 7 - 12.

"Rules book for large-scale Ancient wargaming with miniatures. Includes 11x17 cardstock play-aid with charts. Zip locked."- from the 24-page book

"These rules are designed to give players the feel of Ancient warfare on a large scale. They include the most commonly used units and their capabilities to allow you to make up the Ancient army of your choice and get to playing quickly." - from the introduction

This game's subtitle, 'A playful introduction to the people and cultures of Africa' is perhaps overstating things. This game consists of rolling and moving around the board collecting things that are supposed to tell us about Africa (coconuts, tree, necklace, fish, mask, drum, hut...). Each player has a board with pictures of 9 of the 16 objects to be collected and rolls the die to move around the board and fill up her or his board. The only further 'complication' is that there are some arrow squares on the board, some pointing clockwise, some anticlockwise. It would appear that landing on these squares can change the direction the player is going in. Landing on any other square gets one of the objects, if its one the player needs.

This is intended as a child's first game. My copy is missing the rulebook, but it isn't hard to surmise the basic rules.

Same as Catch Phrase but words or phrases that appear on the readout are familiar to adults and well as children. Anyone who can read can play. Players sit in a circle and divide teams into every other person. One person is selected as the starting player or "Clue Giver." After reading the "target word" on the game's display, the clue giver yells out associated words, hints, sounds until his/her team guesses the target word. As soon as this happens the player presses the Next button and passes the game device to next player who must now give clues to his/her team. All the while the timer is ticking down. Beep...Beep...Beep..Beep..Beep.Beep.BeepBeepBeep! 
If your team is not in possession of the game device when the buzzer goes off and you score! First team to 7 wins!!

This game recreates The Miss America Pageant with players competing in the Swimsuit, Talent, Personality and Evening Gown competitions. The game uses a spinner shaped to look like a television camera. On your turn, you spin the spinner and advance the number of spaces indicated. If you land on a competition space, you draw a card that tells you what score you received for that event. When you have cards from all the competitions, you place your contestant piece on one of the 3 Semi-Final spaces and start a new contestant. It is possible for a player to have 0, 1, 2 or 3 contestants in the Semi-Final judging. When all 3 Semi-Finalist spaces are filled, the player with the highest point score moves her contestant to a Finalist space. A new round is then played and so on until all 5 Finalist spaces are filled around the base of the camera. The spinner is then spun and the contestant in front of the camera pointer is named 4th runner up and removed. This process is repeated eliminating 1 contestant at a time. The remaining contestant is named Miss America, and the player who controls her wins the game.
August the Butterfly is a symmetry learning game for young children Ages 4 and up
